questions.text:
A 25-year-old man is seen in the emergency department for evaluation of abdominal pain. For the past five days, the patient has had a dull ache in the right upper quadrant that does not change with position or eating. The patient has been drinking 13 beers per day for the past three months and his last drink was two days ago. Temperature is 37.0 ºC (98.6 ºF), pulse is 126/min, blood pressure is 155/98 mmHg, and SpO2 is 100% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is tremulous and anxious. Bloodwork is obtained and results are shown below. Abdominal ultrasound shows increased echogenicity and surface nodularity of the liver with patent venous flow into the liver. The gallbladder and pancreas are not well-visualized due to overlying bowel gas. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?  

Laboratory Test
Result
White blood cell count  
4.3 cells/mm3   
Hemoglobin
13.3 g/dL  
AST
210 U/L  
ALT
110 U/L  
Total bilirubin  
7.0 mg/dL  
Prothrombin time  
18 seconds  
Lipase
180 U/L (nl: 0-160 U/L)
questions.solution:
This patient with alcohol use disorder presents with RUQ abdominal pain, elevated transaminases, elevated bilirubin, and elevated prothrombin time, indicating alcohol-induced hepatitis.

Alcohol use disorder can cause hepatitis (such as in this patient), cirrhosis (with chronic long-term use), and pancreatitis. The patient's history can generally differentiate between these three etiologies. Alcohol-induced hepatitis (and sometimes cirrhosis) will typically cause RUQ pain that does not change with eating or position. Pancreatitis can cause RUQ or LUQ pain but classically causes epigastric pain that worsens with eating and with lying down. Older age and a longstanding history of alcohol use increases the likelihood of cirrhosis. Younger patients or those with shorter duration of alcohol use are more likely to have hepatitis or pancreatitis. Nausea, vomiting, and weight loss can be common features due to the underlying alcohol use disorder. Patients with any of these three pathologies may also present with alcohol withdrawal symptoms.

Physical examination in alcohol-induced hepatitis and alcohol-induced pancreatitis may be similar; however, tenderness to palpation is more likely to be in the epigastric region with pancreatitis. Patients with hepatitis may have scleral icterus or jaundice which would not be present with pancreatitis. Patients may also show signs of alcohol withdrawal including tremulousness, anxiety/agitation, confusion, and hallucinations. Patients with severe alcohol-induced hepatitis may also have asterixis. Patients with cirrhosis will often have other physical examination stigmata of cirrhosis such as ascites, gynecomastia, palmar erythema, and spider angiomata.  

Option Analysis

✅ Alcohol-induced hepatitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Alcohol-induced pancreatitis:
Incorrect: This patient’s pain description is more suggestive of hepatobiliary pathology rather than pancreatitis. In addition, his blood work, including the AST to ALT ratio, indicates alcohol-induced hepatitis.  
❌ Acute cholecystitis:
Incorrect: While not completely ruled out, the pain description is much more suggestive of alcohol-induced hepatitis, and the lack of fever and leukocytosis make cholecystitis much less likely. Patients with biliary pathology are more likely to describe a colicky pain that worsens with eating.  
❌ Alcohol-induced cirrhosis:
Incorrect: The ultrasound findings suggest changes that can be seen in both cirrhosis and alcohol-induced hepatitis. Liver imaging should be repeated in a few months to reassess. While cirrhosis is possible in this case, it is less likely to be seen in a 25-year-old with alcohol use disorder.  
❌ Portal vein thrombosis:
Incorrect: This could cause a similar presentation; however, the portal vein is patent on ultrasound which rules this out.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents to the emergency department due to nausea, vomiting, and right upper quadrant abdominal pain for the past day. The patient drinks one liter of vodka per day and her last drink was about 36 hours ago. Temperature is 37.7 ºC (99.9 ºF), pulse is 122/min, blood pressure is 162/101 mmHg, respiratory rate is 22/min, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is diaphoretic, agitated, and tremulous. During the examination, it appears as though the patient is speaking to someone else in the room, although no one else is present. Serum alcohol level is negative. CBC, CMP, and PT/INR are drawn and the patient’s Maddrey discriminant function is 30 and MELD score is 16, respectively. Which of the following medications should be administered at this time?
questions.solution:
This patient with alcohol use disorder presents with RUQ abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and an elevated Maddrey discriminant function (MDF) and MELD score, indicating alcohol-induced hepatitis. This patient is agitated, tachycardic, tremulous, and having hallucinations indicating severe alcohol withdrawal.

After diagnosing alcohol-induced hepatitis, the next step is to calculate the Maddrey discriminant function (MDF) which uses total bilirubin and prothrombin time (PT). The MELD (model for end-stage liver disease) score can also be calculated using sodium, creatinine, total bilirubin, and INR. Patients with DF >32 or MELD >20 should receive treatment with (methyl)prednisolone or pentoxifylline, if steroids are contraindicated. Patients, like this one, with DF ≤32 or MELD ≤20 should receive supportive care without pharmacologic treatment of the hepatitis. All patients should have the underlying alcohol use disorder addressed and treated with alcohol cessation counseling and potential medications such as oral naltrexone.

This patient also has severe alcohol withdrawal which should be treated. Severe alcohol withdrawal can have life-threatening consequences such as delirium tremens and seizures. Patients should receive benzodiazepine therapy to help treat symptoms and prevent seizures. Most severe complications occur within 48-72 hours of the patient’s last drink, but this is not always the case. Lorazepam and diazepam are both frequently used, with oral or IV routes depending upon the severity of the symptoms.  

Option Analysis

✅ Intravenous lorazepam:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Intravenous methylprednisolone:
Incorrect: This patient likely has alcohol-induced hepatitis; however since the Maddrey discriminant function is <32 and the MELD score is <20, no treatment is indicated.  
❌ Intravenous naltrexone:
Incorrect: This would be appropriate for an opioid overdose which would cause the patient to be lethargic, not hyperactive and anxious.  
❌ Oral prednisolone:
Incorrect: This patient likely has alcohol-induced hepatitis; however, since the Maddrey discriminant function is <32 and the MELD score is <20, no treatment is indicated.  
❌ Oral pentoxifylline:
Incorrect: This patient likely has alcohol-induced hepatitis; however since the Maddrey discriminant function is <32 and the MELD score is <20, no treatment is indicated. Steroids are preferred over pentoxifylline unless there is a contraindication to steroid use.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with a history of compensated cirrhosis due to nonalcoholic steatohepatitis presents to the emergency department with two days of worsening abdominal pain that comes and goes abruptly. The pain is most pronounced in the right upper quadrant. He notes an increase in fatigue and abdominal girth. He has not had any recent alcohol intake, changes in medications, or history of similar episodes. Temperature is 37℃ (98.6℉), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 122/84 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. There is scleral icterus. The abdomen is tender to palpation diffusely with a positive fluid wave and splenomegaly. Laboratory tests reveal thrombocytopenia, elevated bilirubin, and mild transaminitis consistent with known cirrhosis. A doppler ultrasound reveals hyperechoic material in the portal vein with impaired blood flow. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient with compensated cirrhosis presents with symptoms suggestive of portal vein thrombosis (PVT), confirmed by doppler ultrasound showing hyperechoic material and impaired blood flow in the portal vein. The best next step in management is therapeutic anticoagulation with low molecular weight heparin (LMWH).    

PVT refers to thrombosis within the portal vein that results in partial or complete vascular obstruction. This condition is commonly associated with cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma, and can result in multiple complications, including esophageal and gastric varices, as well as cavernous transformation, pylephlebitis, and mesenteric ischemia.    

If a patient presents with findings suggestive of PVT, the first step is to perform an ABCDE assessment to determine if the patient is unstable or stable. If the patient is unstable, airway, breathing, and circulation should be managed. Next, IV access and continuous vital sign monitoring, including blood pressure, heart rate, and pulse oximetry should be obtained. Unstable patients should be assessed for severe complications of portal vein thrombosis, like variceal bleeding or mesenteric infarction. For variceal bleeding, an endoscopy should be performed with variceal banding or sclerotherapy. In the case of mesenteric infarction, surgical consultation is necessary.

Option Analysis

❌ Paracentesis:
Incorrect: Paracentesis, although useful in assessing new-onset ascites and for diagnosing spontaneous bacterial peritonitis, does not directly address the thrombotic event in the portal vein. Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) should be started in this patient. 
✅ Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH):
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Apixaban:
Incorrect: Apixaban is a direct oral anticoagulant and reports have indicated decreased efficacy when used to treat portal vein thrombosis (PVT) in patients with cirrhosis. More research is needed before recommendations regarding its use can be made.
❌ Surgical thrombectomy:
Incorrect: Surgical thrombectomy may be used for patients with portal vein thrombosis (PVT) and intestinal infarction who are undergoing surgery for intestinal infarction where thrombectomy can be performed during laparotomy. Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) should be started in this patient. 
❌ Systemic thrombolytic therapy:
Incorrect: Systemic thrombolytic therapy is not appropriate management for acute portal vein thrombosis since it can lead to bleeding, especially in patients with cirrhosis. However, several studies have demonstrated some success with catheter-based thrombolysis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of progressively worsening right upper quadrant pain, fever, and chills. He was treated 5 days ago with antibiotics for diverticulitis. At first, he had improvement of the initial left lower quadrant pain, but he then developed right upper quadrant abdominal pain, fevers, and chills. He has no personal or family history of a hypercoagulable state. His medical history is significant for hypertension, managed with lisinopril. Temperature is 39℃ (100.4℉), pulse is 88/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, blood pressure is 112/74 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Abdominal examination reveals abdominal tenderness in the right upper quadrant and guarding, without rebound tenderness. Laboratory tests show leukocytosis, normal transaminases, and normal INR. A bedside Doppler ultrasound reveals hyperechoic material in the portal vein with impaired blood flow from partial occlusion. What is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient, who has recently been treated for diverticulitis, presents with diffuse abdominal pain, fevers, chills, and right upper quadrant tenderness. Doppler ultrasound shows hyperechoic material in the portal vein with impaired blood flow from partial occlusion. These findings are consistent with septic thrombophlebitis of the portal vein, or pylephlebitis, which is a rare complication of intra-abdominal infections. The best next step in management is to perform a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis to look for the source of infection.    

Patients with portal vein thrombosis (PVT) can be asymptomatic or present with nonspecific signs and symptoms. They may present with acute abdominal pain or progressively worsening abdominal pain. The abdominal pain may be associated with nausea or vomiting. Many of the clinical findings that patients present with will be related to the underlying cause of PVT (e.g. spider angioma, ascites, variceal hemorrhage in cirrhosis). Risk factors such as cirrhosis, hepatocellular carcinoma, recent abdominal surgery, and hypercoagulable state (including inherited thrombophilias or use of oral contraceptives) should raise the index of suspicion.  

On physical examination, patients with PVT may have abdominal tenderness typically without guarding. Guarding may be secondary to intra-abdominal infection. Patients with pylephlebitis may have a tender liver and fever. Patients with PVT may have signs of chronic liver disease (e.g. jaundice, ascites, spider angiomata). In severe cases, signs of systemic illness such as fever or hypotension may be present. 

Option Analysis

❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) abdomen/pelvis:
Incorrect: MRI abdomen/pelvis would not be helpful in the acute setting to diagnose an intraabdominal infection. 
❌ Abdominal radiograph:
Incorrect: An abdominal x-ray would not help diagnose suspected diverticulitis. 
❌ Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography:
Incorrect: Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is not indicated, as it is primarily used for evaluation of biliary or pancreatic ductal pathologies. 
✅ Computed tomography (CT) abdomen/pelvis :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Upper endoscopy:
Incorrect: An upper endoscopy is not appropriate for evaluation of suspected diverticulitis and associated complications.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his partner for evaluation of altered mental status. His family reports worsening confusion over the past 24 hours, and the patient is now difficult to arouse. The patient has a history of cirrhosis due to nonalcoholic steatohepatitis. Temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 110/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, blood pressure is 88/60 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 87% on room air. The patient appears stuporous and is unable to answer orientation questions or follow commands. The patient appears jaundiced. The abdomen is distended and tender with a positive fluid wave test. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of cirrhosis presents with altered mental status, ascites, and a tender abdomen. He is unstable and cannot protect his airway. Therefore, immediate stabilization with endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation is necessary. The most likely diagnoses are either spontaneous bacterial peritonitis or spontaneous bacterial peritonitis with hepatic encephalopathy. Either way, stabilization is the priority before further diagnostic studies or treatments are performed.       

Many patients with hepatic encephalopathy present in a near comatose state. Thus, before addressing the underlying cause with treatments like lactulose or treating underlying infections, it is crucial to secure the airway and provide supplemental oxygen to maintain adequate oxygenation (oxygen saturation >90%) as part of the ABCDE (Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, Exposure) assessment.   

Option Analysis

✅ Endotracheal intubation :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Computed tomography (CT) head without contrast:
Incorrect: A head CT scan may be necessary if there is suspicion for an alternative etiology of altered mental status, such as intracranial hemorrhage. However, this patient with cirrhosis and confusion and ascites most likely has hepatic encephalopathy. He is unstable; therefore, immediate stabilization takes precedence.  
❌ Lactulose:
Incorrect: Lactulose is used for managing patients with hepatic encephalopathy. However, it should be administered after stabilizing the patient’s airway, breathing, and circulation. 
❌ Broad-spectrum antibiotics:
Incorrect: Antibiotics would be necessary to treat a suspected spontaneous bacterial peritonitis, which may have precipitated hepatic encephalopathy in this patient. However, antibiotic administration should follow securing the airway and stabilizing the patient. 
❌ Noninvasive positive-pressure ventilation:
Incorrect: Noninvasive positive-pressure ventilation (e.g. BiPAP) is typically used for patients with respiratory distress who can protect their airway. Given the patient's stuporous state, noninvasive ventilation is inappropriate. It may result in aspiration or worsening respiratory failure. Invasive airway management (i.e. intubation) is required for this patient.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic due to new yellowing of the skin. This has been gradually worsening for the past week. The patient has never experienced this before. Past medical history is significant for HIV, hypertension, and active tuberculosis. Current medications include bictegravir-emtricitabine-tenofovir, losartan, rifampin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol. Vital signs are unremarkable. On physical examination, the patient is noticeably jaundiced. Bloodwork is drawn in the office and the results are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
 
Serum Test
Result   
Haptoglobin
Increased
LDH
190 U/L (nml: 140-280 U/L)
Total Bilirubin
6.0 mg/dL
Direct Bilirubin
0.5 mg/dL
AST
19 U/L
ALT
15 U/L
questions.solution:
Unconjugated (indirect) hyperbilirubinemia is typically caused by one of three factors: increased production (hemolysis), decreased hepatic uptake, or impaired hepatic conjugation. Hemolysis generally presents with anemia, reticulocytosis, elevated LDH, and decreased haptoglobin. Peripheral smear can help differentiate between the causes of hemolysis. Decreased hepatic uptake can occur due to medications (e.g. rifampin) as seen in this case, portosystemic shunting (e.g. after TIPS procedure), cirrhosis, and congestive hepatopathy from right heart failure. Impaired bilirubin conjugation occurs in hereditary diseases, such as Crigler-Najjar and Gilbert syndrome.

This patient presenting with new unconjugated (indirect) hyperbilirubinemia in the setting of treatment for active TB with rifampin likely has medication-induced (iatrogenic) hyperbilirubinemia. Several medications (such as probenecid, rifampin, and others) can impair the hepatic uptake of bilirubin. Unconjugated bilirubin then gets absorbed into the bloodstream without conjugation and leads to elevated serum unconjugated (indirect) bilirubin. This patient’s LDH and haptoglobin point away from hemolysis, the history does not suggest Gilbert syndrome, and the normal transaminases (AST and ALT) point away from hepatic pathology. The next step in management would be to discontinue the rifampin and follow the bilirubin.  

Option Analysis

✅ Medication-induced hyperbilirubinemia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Gilbert syndrome:
Incorrect: This patient has never had any episodes of jaundice prior to this and is now 48 years old. This makes it unlikely to be Gilbert syndrome, which is a congenital disorder of impaired bilirubin conjugation. In addition, the current use of rifampin is a much more likely cause for his unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.  
❌ Warm autoimmune hemolytic anemia:
Incorrect: Warm AIHA (usually IgG-mediated) can present with unconjugated (indirect) hyperbilirubinemia. While we do not know this patient’s hemoglobin, a haptoglobin that is normal and not decreased and an LDH in the normal range rules out any significant hemolysis.  
❌ Cold autoimmune hemolytic anemia:
Incorrect: Cold AIHA (usually IgM-mediated) can present with unconjugated (indirect) hyperbilirubinemia. While we do not know this patient’s hemoglobin, a haptoglobin that is in the normal range and not decreased and a normal LDH rules out any significant hemolysis.  
❌ Hereditary spherocytosis:
Incorrect: A normal haptoglobin that is not decreased and a normal LDH that is not increased rules out significant hemolysis. This makes hereditary spherocytosis unlikely to be the cause of this patient’s hyperbilirubinemia.

questions.text:
A 51-year-old man presents to the emergency department due to lethargy and weakness. The symptoms started abruptly three days ago and have gotten slowly worse since then. The patient has no significant past medical history and takes no medications. Temperature is 36.8ºC (98.2ºF), pulse is 96/min, blood pressure is 98/61 mmHg, respirations are 16/min and SpO2 is 99% on room air. On physical examination the patient is pale and lethargic. There are no abnormal findings on abdominal exam. There is no lower extremity edema. Bloodwork is obtained and results are shown below. Which of the following tests should be ordered next?
 
Serum Test
Result
Hemoglobin
6.8 g/dL
Haptoglobin
Decreased
Total Bilirubin
7.4 mg/dL
LDH
450 U/L (nml: 140-280 U/L)
questions.solution:
In patients with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, hemolytic anemia should be ruled out early because some causes can be life-threatening. Hemolytic anemia presents with anemia, reticulocytosis, elevated unconjugated (indirect) bilirubin, elevated LDH, and decreased haptoglobin. Hemolytic anemia can be life-threatening in the case of autoimmune hemolytic anemia or thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura. These disorders should always be considered and ruled out in cases of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. The clinical vignette is highly suggestive of hemolytic anemia; so further testing should be performed, including peripheral smear and the direct antiglobulin Coombs test to look for autoimmune hemolytic anemia.

If hemolytic anemia is ruled out as the cause of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, then further testing should be directed at investigating the liver for things that may cause impaired hepatic uptake (such as congestive hepatopathy, cirrhosis, and portosystemic shunting). If there is no liver pathology, this may indicate hereditary (e.g. Crigler-Najjar, Gilbert syndrome) causes of impaired conjugation or medications as the cause of impaired hepatic uptake.  

Option Analysis

✅ Direct antiglobulin (Coombs) test:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ G6PD assay:
Incorrect: This patient’s blood work indicates hemolytic anemia, which can be caused by G6PD deficiency. However, G6PD assays are unreliable during an active attack and should not be checked until the hemolysis is resolved.  
❌ Fractionated bilirubin:
Incorrect: In this patient, the severity of the anemia, elevated LDH, and decreased haptoglobin are suggestive of hemolytic anemia. Fractionating the bilirubin would not provide additional useful information at this point.  
❌ GGT:
Incorrect: An elevated serum gamma glutamyl transpeptidase (GGT) can indicate hepatobiliary pathology, especially when it is unclear whether an elevation in alkaline phosphatase is from bone or biliary pathology. This patient has hemolytic anemia, and this test is unlikely to provide additional useful information.  
❌ Abdominal ultrasound:
Incorrect: While abdominal ultrasound is an appropriate test to order in patients with elevated bilirubin and/or hemolytic anemia, a Coombs test should be ordered first to determine if the cause is autoimmune hemolytic anemia.

questions.text:
A 39-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of right upper abdominal pain, vomiting, and confusion for the past 2 days. Her temperature is 39.7 °C (103.6 °F), blood pressure is 115/65 mm Hg, and pulse rate is 104/min. The patient is alert but confused. Physical examination shows scleral icterus and right-upper-quadrant tenderness with guarding. Laboratory evaluation is shown below. Abdominal ultrasound demonstrates multiple stones in the gallbladder without gallbladder wall thickening or pericholecystic fluid. The diameter of the common bile duct (CBD) is 8 mm, with a small stone visualized. Blood cultures are obtained and empiric treatment with intravenous piperacillin-tazobactam is initiated. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?  

Laboratory value
Result
Complete Blood Count (CBC)

Hemoglobin
13 g/dL
White blood cell count (WBC)
13,000/mm3
Liver Function Tests

Alkaline Phosphatase (ALP)
300 u/L
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT)
238 u/L
Aspartate aminotransferase (AST)
159 u/L
Total bilirubin
6 mg/dL
INR
1.3
Serum chemistry

Lipase
50 U/L
questions.solution:
This patient with high grade fever, right upper quadrant abdominal pain, jaundice, and change in mental status has 4 of the 5 components of Reynolds pentad, which can be seen in patients with acute cholangitis. Liver function testing demonstrates a cholestatic pattern of liver injury and ultrasound shows an obstructing stone in the common bile duct. This patient should be treated with immediate antimicrobial therapy in combination with urgent decompression of the biliary tree with endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP).

In cases where ERCP fails or is unavailable, endoscopic ultrasound-guided biliary drainage can be performed. If endoscopic drainage is unavailable, percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography can be used to drain the infected biliary system and extract any obstructing stones. If these interventions are unsuccessful or unavailable, then a surgical approach is recommended. Definitive treatment with cholecystectomy should be performed during the initial hospitalization or within 2 weeks to reduce the risk of recurrence and complications.

Option Analysis

❌ Laparoscopic biliary drainage:
Incorrect: Laparoscopic biliary drainage with stone removal is invasive and is reserved for cases where ERCP has failed or is contraindicated.  
❌ Urgent cholecystectomy:
Incorrect: The most appropriate next step is to decompress the common bile duct via ERCP. Though cholecystectomy should be performed during the initial hospital stay to prevent recurrence, it is not the first step in management.  
✅ Urgent endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP):
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid (HIDA) scan:
Incorrect: Cholescintigraphy using 99mTc-HIDA scan is indicated in patients with suspected cholecystitis not evident on ultrasound. It is not used to evaluate or treat patients with acute cholangitis.  
❌ Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP):
Incorrect: MRCP is typically obtained for nonurgent evaluation of suspected choledocholitihiasis that is not evident on ultrasound. It should not be performed in this patient with life-threatening acute cholangitis that has been confirmed with ultrasound.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man was brought to the emergency department for evaluation of vomiting and confusion for one day. The patient has a history of alcohol use disorder and chronic back pain following a motor vehicle accident several years ago. The patient has a history of drinking up to 2 pints of vodka per day. Current medications include oxycodone/acetaminophen 5-325 mg as needed every 2 hours. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. The patient appears lethargic and is only oriented to person. Physical examination reveals scleral icterus and jaundice. There are no signs of chronic liver disease. Laboratory studies are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
 
Laboratory value
Result
Alkaline Phosphatase (ALP)
100 u/L
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT)
1,549 u/L
Aspartate aminotransferase (AST)
1,845 u/L
Total bilirubin
3 mg/dL
Direct bilirubin
1 mg/dL
INR
1.3
White blood cell (WBC) count
10,000/mm3
Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)300 u/L
questions.solution:
This patient with vomiting, lethargy, altered mental status, and supratherapeutic use of acetaminophen in the setting of heavy alcohol use most likely has had an acetaminophen overdose resulting in drug-induced liver injury.

Patients with chronic alcohol use disorder appear to be at increased risk for hepatotoxicity following ingestion of repeated, supratherapeutic (or even therapeutic) doses of acetaminophen. Alcohol induces CYP2E1 which results in accelerated metabolism of acetaminophen and enhanced generation of N-acetyl-p-benzoquinoneimine (NAPQI), the primary hepatotoxic metabolite.

Acute acetaminophen overdose presents with nausea, vomiting, lethargy, and jaundice, with a hepatocellular pattern of injury. Aminotransferases are typically >1000 u/L. Elevations of INR and total bilirubin, oliguria, and renal function abnormalities can also be seen. Treatment is guided by serum acetaminophen concentrations using the modified Rumack-Matthew treatment nomogram. If indicated, N-acetylcysteine therapy is recommended.  

Option Analysis

❌ Acute autoimmune hepatitis:
Incorrect: Acute autoimmune hepatitis is typically seen in women with a history of autoimmune disease. Clinically, it presents with fatigue, abdominal discomfort, anorexia, and weight loss. This patient’s use of acetaminophen in the setting of alcohol use makes drug-induced liver injury more likely.  
❌ Acute viral hepatitis:
Incorrect: Acute viral hepatitis usually presents with right upper quadrant abdominal pain, fever, and myalgias. This patient’s use of acetaminophen in the setting of alcohol use makes drug-induced liver injury more likely.  
✅ Drug-induced liver injury:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ischemic hepatitis:
Incorrect: Ischemic hepatitis is typically seen in patients with significant hemodynamic instability (e.g. patients with septic shock). LDH is significantly elevated in these patients.  
❌ Alcohol induced hepatitis:
Incorrect: Patients with alcohol-induced hepatitis typically have moderate elevations in aminotransferases (rarely higher than 500 u/L) with AST: ALT 2:1. They typically have moderate neutrophilic leukocytosis. This patient’s AST and ALT levels are significantly elevated in the setting of supratherapeutic acetaminophen use, making drug-induced liver injury more likely.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of 3 days of yellowing skin, lethargy, anorexia, nausea, and vomiting. Medical history is significant for insulin-dependent type 1 diabetes. She is not on any other medications. Vitals are within normal limits. The patient appears lethargic but is alert and oriented. She has evidence of jaundice and scleral icterus without signs of cirrhosis. Abdominal exam is significant for right upper quadrant pain. Initial laboratory evaluation is shown below. Which of the following tests should be ordered next?
 
Laboratory value
Result
Alkaline Phosphatase (ALP)
205 u/L
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT)
1134 u/L
Aspartate aminotransferase (AST)
1231 u/L
Total bilirubin
24 mg/dL
INR
3.0
Serum iron
100 mcg/dL
Serum transferrin
250 mg/dL

choices.text: Serum anti nuclear (ANA) and anti-smooth muscle (ASMA) antibodies

questions.solution:
Autoimmune hepatitis (AIH) typically presents as a chronic inflammatory liver disease; however, some patients can have an acute presentation that may progress to autoimmune acute liver failure as seen in this patient. Since patients with autoimmune hepatitis can respond dramatically to corticosteroids, it is important to consider autoimmune hepatitis in patients presenting with acute liver failure. Given this patient’s age, gender, and history of autoimmune disease (type 1 diabetes mellitus), and the fact that she has no prior history of liver disease, she should be tested for autoimmune hepatitis. She should be evaluated with serum anti-nuclear (ANA) and anti-smooth muscle (ASMA) antibody testing.

Other causes of acute liver failure should be ruled out with appropriate testing. These include acetaminophen toxicity, viral hepatitis, ischemic hepatic injury, Wilson disease, alcoholic hepatitis, and HELLP syndrome in pregnant patients.  

Option Analysis

✅ Serum anti nuclear (ANA) and anti-smooth muscle (ASMA) antibodies:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Serum antimitochondrial antibodies:
Incorrect: Serum antimitochondrial antibodies are positive in patients with primary biliary cirrhosis (PBC), which typically presents with a cholestatic pattern on bloodwork. Patients usually are asymptomatic or have associated pruritus.  
❌ HFE gene testing:
Incorrect: HFE gene testing is used to diagnose hemochromatosis. Clinical presentation varies from asymptomatic to nonspecific symptoms of fatigue to signs of iron overload in multiple organs (arthropathy, skin hyperpigmentation, abdominal pain, hepatomegaly, etc.). Patients exhibit iron overload on laboratory evaluation. This patient’s iron and transferrin levels are within normal limits.  
❌ Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP):
Incorrect: MRCP is used in patients with a cholestatic pattern of liver injury when ultrasound does not reveal extrahepatic obstruction (e.g. in patients with primary sclerosing cholangitis). This patient’s liver function testing shows a hepatocellular pattern of injury.  
❌ ERCP:
Incorrect: ERCP is the initial test for patients presenting with acute cholangitis since it can be used for both diagnosis and treatment with biliary decompression. This patient’s blood work shows a hepatic pattern of injury and not the cholestatic pattern that would be seen with acute cholangitis.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by EMS after his partner found him at home lethargic and confused. His partner states that over the last week, he has been easily agitated, forgetting simple tasks, and sleeping during the day.  He told his partner he was feeling nauseous. His partner states he has a substance use disorder and uses IV drugs. He has no significant medical history. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 118/80 mmHg. On exam, he is somnolent but arousable to sound and is able to follow commands. Eye exam shows scleral icterus without papilledema and with a normal pupillary exam  Abdominal tenderness is present in the right upper quadrant. Flapping is noted when he extends his arms and cocks his hands back. Head CT is normal and toxicology screen is negative. Lab results are shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?  

Laboratory value
Result
AST
967 units/L
ALT
1,132 units/L
Total bilirubin
7.3 mg/dL
INR
1.9
Anti-HBc IgM
+
HBsAg
-
HBsAb
-
questions.solution:
This patient’s altered mental status and asterixis in conjunction with abnormal AST/ALT and liver function tests is suggestive of hepatic encephalopathy, which is a life-threatening brain disorder caused by liver disease.  The laboratory and exam findings are consistent with acute hepatitis B infection (HBV) during the window period where Hepatitis B surface antibody and antigen are negative, but IgM antibodies to core antigen are positive.  When acute Hepatitis B infection has progressed to this severity, options for definitive treatment are limited, and surgical consultation for liver transplant should be obtained urgently as patients can rapidly deteriorate.

Hepatitis B infection is a blood-borne viral infection that can present during the acute stage on a continuum from asymptomatic disease to fulminant hepatic failure.  Early disease presents with generalized symptoms of fatigue, nausea, sleep disturbances, and behavioral changes, with or without right upper quadrant abdominal pain, pruritus, and jaundice.  Hallmarks of fulminant hepatic failure include altered mental status, asterixis, ascites, GI bleeding, and cerebral edema.  Laboratory results in severe disease typically include extreme elevations of liver transaminases, coagulopathy with an INR ≥ 1.5, and elevated bilirubin.

The first priority in treating patients with acute hepatitis B infection and fulminant liver failure is to stabilize the patient, obtain IV access, and arrange for close monitoring with frequent checks of vital signs.  Antiviral therapies will not eradicate the virus but may help reduce viral replication and reduce the likelihood of progression to chronic infection.  They are typically prescribed in cases of severe disease or protracted illness from acute hepatitis B infection. Most cases of acute HBV infection will resolve spontaneously with supportive measures only, but severe disease with fulminant liver failure has a high mortality rate without liver transplantation.  

Option Analysis

✅ Surgical consultation for liver transplant:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Surgical consultation for VP shunt:
Incorrect:  Shunting fluid from the brain to the abdomen is a treatment for cerebral edema.  This patient has no papilledema and a normal head CT. Given his lab results, he likely has acute Hepatitis B infection with hepatic encephalopathy.  
❌ Administration of zidovudine:
Incorrect: Zidovudine is used to treat HIV, it is not used in the management of acute hepatitis B infection and fulminant liver failure and could contribute to liver damage.  
❌ Administration of interferon-⍺:
Incorrect: Pegylated interferon can be used to treat young patients with well-compensated liver disease from chronic Hepatitis B who do not want to be on long-term treatment. It is not a treatment for fulminant hepatic failure and hepatic encephalopathy.  
❌ Administration of naloxone:
Incorrect:  Naloxone reverses opiate overdoses, however, this patient does not have miotic pupils, is arousable and able to follow commands, and is breathing on his own.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman comes to the clinic for evaluation of generalized fatigue and pruritus. Review of systems is otherwise unremarkable. She has no family history of liver disease. Past medical history is noncontributory and she does not take any medication. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows moist mucous membranes. Neck is supple. Lungs are clear to auscultation. No ascites or organomegaly is noted. Laboratory findings are shown below. Right upper quadrant ultrasound shows a normal appearing liver, gallbladder, and biliary tract. Antimitochondrial antibody titer is 1:80. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?  

Laboratory value  
Result
Complete Blood Count  

Hemoglobin
12.5 g/dL
Leukocyte count  
5500/mm3   
Platelet Count  
200,000/mm3   
Serum Chemistry  

Sodium
142 mEq/L  
Potassium
4.2 mEq/L  
Chloride
95 mEq/L  
Creatinine
1.1 mg/dL  
Alanine aminotransferase  
20 U/L
Aspartate aminotransferase  
21 U/L
Serum albumin  
4 g/dL
Serum total bilirubin  
2.1 mg/dL
Total protein  
6 g/dL
Alkaline phosphatase level  
250 U/L
questions.solution:
This patient with generalized fatigue and pruritus was found to have elevated alkaline phosphatase and mildly elevated bilirubin, suggesting cholestatic liver disease. Given the normal ultrasound and positive antimitochondrial antibody titer, primary biliary cholangitis (PBC) is the most likely diagnosis. This patient should be started on ursodeoxycholic acid (UDCA).

PBC is an autoimmune disorder that affects the small and medium intrahepatic bile ducts. Upon diagnosis, the primary treatment for PBC is UDCA. UDCA is a hydrophilic bile acid that works by increasing the hydrophilic index of circulating bile acid, stimulating hepatocellular and biliary secretions, cytoprotection, immunomodulation and anti-inflammatory effects. It is associated with histologic improvement, increased survival rates, and reduced reliance on liver transplantation. It is generally well-tolerated, with some patients having weight gain as a side effect. It leads to biochemical response with normal alkaline phosphatase levels within a year of starting treatment. In the meantime, pruritus can be treated symptomatically with antihistamines or cholestyramine.  

Option Analysis

❌ Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP)  :
Incorrect: MRCP would be beneficial for further evaluation if primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) was suspected, which is more common in men and is usually associated with other autoimmune disorders (e.g. Inflammatory bowel disease), and has ultrasound findings of extrahepatic bile duct dilation. None of which are seen in this patient. Moreover, the antimitochondrial antibody titer is consistent with a diagnosis of PBC.  
❌ Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP)  :
Incorrect: ERCP should be considered if cholestasis is suspected to be secondary to mechanical obstruction (choledocholithiasis) or strictures (e.g. primary sclerosing cholangitis). Given the normal right upper quadrant ultrasound and elevated antimitochondrial antibodies, primary biliary cholangitis is the most likely diagnosis, which is treated with ursodeoxycholic acid.  
❌ Furosemide:
Incorrect: Furosemide would be appropriate if cholestasis led to cirrhosis of the liver and concomitant ascites. Given that  there are no signs of volume overload on physical examination and a normal liver is seen on the right upper quadrant ultrasound, furosemide is not necessary at this time.  
❌ Referral for liver transplant evaluation:
Incorrect: Referral for liver transplant evaluation would be appropriate for advanced cholestasis leading to cirrhosis of the liver. This patient has no sign of volume overload and normal ultrasound of the liver, and should therefore be treated with ursodeoxycholic acid first.  
✅ Ursodeoxycholic acid:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents to the emergency department due to malaise and headache. These symptoms started four days ago and have progressively worsened to the point that the patient has trouble getting out of bed. The patient went to an urgent care six days ago for acute bronchitis and was given moxifloxacin, which he only took for two days. The patient has no known medical history and takes no medications. Temperature is 38.4ºC (101.1ºF), pulse is 96/min, blood pressure is 112/75 mmHg, respirations are 16/min, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 100% on room air. On physical examination, the patient has icteric conjunctiva and appears lethargic. Serum studies show a hemoglobin of 8.1 g/dL and indirect bilirubin of 5.7 mg/dL. Peripheral blood smear shows red blood cells with normal morphology and ring-shaped structures within several cells. Which of the following historical elements is likely to be present?

choices.text: Recent onset of lower extremity edema

questions.solution:
Unconjugated (indirect) hyperbilirubinemia is typically caused by one of three things: increased production of bilirubin from hemolysis, decreased hepatic uptake of bilirubin, or impaired hepatic conjugation of bilirubin. Hemolysis generally presents with anemia, reticulocytosis, elevated LDH, and decreased haptoglobin. The peripheral smear can often help differentiate between the causes of hemolysis. Decreased hepatic uptake can occur due to medications (e.g. rifampin), portosystemic shunting (e.g. after TIPS procedure), or congestive hepatopathy from right heart failure. Impaired bilirubin conjugation occurs in hereditary diseases, such as Crigler-Najjar and Gilbert syndrome.

History and physical examination can help determine which of the three major causes of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia exists. Patients with hemolytic anemia may present with significant fatigue, weakness, or shortness of breath; especially if the anemia is relatively acute in onset. History should assess for causative factors of hemolysis, such as recent tick exposure (e.g. babesiosis); prior heart valve replacement; or recent travel with exposure to malaria, which is likely the case in this patient. Associated symptoms of malaria include headache and fever. Patients may appear pale and/or jaundiced on physical examination with any of the causes of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Splenomegaly can be present in malaria as well as hereditary spherocytosis. History may indicate an obvious cause of impaired hepatic uptake of bilirubin, such as cirrhosis, recent TIPS procedure, and symptoms of congestive heart failure. Patients with Gilbert syndrome will have a history of episodic jaundice.  

Option Analysis

✅ Recent travel outside the country:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Family history of anemia:
Incorrect: Family history of anemia could indicate a familial cause of hemolytic anemia, such as hereditary spherocytosis; however, this patient’s presentation is much more concerning for malaria given his headaches, malaise, fever, and likely hemolytic anemia.  
❌ Family history of Gilbert syndrome:
Incorrect: Gilbert syndrome can cause mild unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia in patients who are undergoing stress; however, this patient has significant hyperbilirubinemia and findings much more suggestive of malaria.  
❌ Recent exposure to moxifloxacin:
Incorrect: In G6PD deficiency-mediated hemolysis caused by an antibiotic like moxifloxacin, the peripheral smear would be expected to show Heinz bodies or bite cells. Instead, this patient’s peripheral blood smear shows ring-shaped structures consistent with malaria.  
❌ Recent onset of lower extremity edema:
Incorrect: Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia can be seen in patients with congestive hepatopathy (heart failure affecting the liver) or cirrhosis, which can lead to decreased hepatic uptake of bilirubin. However, this vignette is more suggestive of malaria.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman comes to the clinic for evaluation of the insidious-onset of fatigue and yellowing of the skin. She reports feeling fatigued for years but attributed it to work-related stress and never sought medical attention. She also notes generalized itching and yellowing of her eyes. Medical history is significant for Sjogren syndrome for which she takes pilocarpine. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows jaundice, scleral icterus, and excoriations over the bilateral forearms. The initial laboratory evaluation is shown. Which of the following tests should be ordered next to help make the diagnosis?

choices.text: Serum anti nuclear (ANA) and anti-smooth muscle (ASMA) antibodies

questions.solution:
This patient with Sjogren syndrome, fatigue, pruritus, jaundice, and a cholestatic pattern of liver injury (hyperbilirubinemia and elevated alkaline phosphatase) should be evaluated for  primary biliary cholangitis (PBC). The most appropriate test to perform is serum antimitochondrial antibody (AMA) testing, which is 95 percent sensitive and 98 percent specific for PBC.

The differential diagnosis for hyperbilirubinemia should be approached based on history and physical examination findings, symptom course (acute or chronic), and the pattern of liver injury (hepatocellular or cholestatic). In patients with a cholestatic pattern of liver injury, an abdominal ultrasound should be obtained. In this middle-aged woman with typical findings of PBC, antimitochondrial antibodies should be obtained.

Diagnosis of PBC can be made based on findings of an elevated ALP (at least 1.5 times the upper limit of normal) and the presence of AMAs. If either of these two tests are negative and the presentation is highly suspicious of PBD, biopsy for histologic evaluation can be performed.  Findings of nonsuppurative destructive cholangitis and destruction of interlobular bile ducts is consistent with a diagnosis of PBC.  

Option Analysis

❌ Serum anti nuclear (ANA) and anti-smooth muscle (ASMA) antibodies:
Incorrect: Serum ANA and ASMA antibodies are used to evaluate for autoimmune hepatitis. Patients with autoimmune hepatitis typically have a hepatocellular pattern of liver disease with elevations in aminotransferases and normal alkaline phosphatase levels.  
✅ Serum antimitochondrial antibodies:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ HFE gene testing:
Incorrect: HFE gene testing is used to test for hemochromatosis. Clinical presentation varies from asymptomatic to nonspecific symptoms of fatigue to signs of iron overload in multiple organs. Patients will have elevated AST and ALT and evidence of iron overload on laboratory evaluation. This patient has a cholecystic pattern of liver injury and normal iron and transferrin levels.  
❌ Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP):
Incorrect: MRCP would be appropriate to evaluate for choledocholithiasis or primary sclerosing cholangitis when abdominal ultrasound is equivocal. Choledocholithiasis typically presents with biliary-type pain that is not seen in this patient. Patients with PSC typically have associated inflammatory bowel disease.  
❌ Serum ceruloplasmin:
Incorrect: Serum ceruloplasmin is used to diagnose Wilson disease, which typically presents with neuropsychiatric symptoms and/or physical examination findings of Kayser-Fleischer rings in the eyes. A hepatocellular pattern of liver injury would be expected, not a cholestatic pattern.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by family for evaluation after three episodes of vomiting blood and “coffee grounds.” The patient has alcohol use disorder and currently drinks 6-8 beers every evening. The patient has no other diagnosed medical conditions but has not seen a physician in more than 10 years and does not currently take any medications. Temperature is 37.2 ºC (99.0 °F), pulse is 116/min, blood pressure is 86/48 mmHg, respiratory rate is 18/minute, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. The patient is awake and able to answer all questions but is slow to respond. Skin examination is significant for jaundice and multiple spider angiomas on his chest. The abdomen is distended and non-tender with a positive fluid wave. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient’s alcohol use disorder and physical examination findings of jaundice, spider angiomas, and ascites strongly suggest underlying cirrhosis. The hematemesis is concerning for bleeding from gastroesophageal varices, which are caused by increased pressure from portal hypertension. Acute variceal bleeds have a high mortality rate. Patients with cirrhosis typically have coagulopathies and have significantly increased risk of infection.

The first step in evaluation and management is to perform the ABCDE assessment to determine hemodynamic stability. The low blood pressure and elevated heart rate indicate the patient is unstable and therefore IV fluids should be started immediately for volume resuscitation. If the hematemesis is severe, endotracheal intubation may be necessary for airway protection.

After resuscitation, a complete blood count and PT/INR should be obtained to assess for anemia, thrombocytopenia, and coagulopathy to guide the use of blood products. A complete metabolic panel should be obtained to assess transaminases and bilirubin. This will also provide serum sodium and creatinine, which should be used to calculate a MELD (model for end-stage liver disease) score. Once the patient is stable, paracentesis should be performed for both diagnostic and therapeutic purposes.

After IV fluids, patients with bleeding that is likely from esophageal varices should receive prophylactic antibiotics (e.g. ceftriaxone) to prevent infection, and possibly red blood cell transfusions for severe anemia and vitamin K (or fresh frozen plasma) for severe coagulopathy. Octreotide (a splanchnic vasoconstrictor) should be started and upper endoscopy (EGD) should be performed early for diagnosis and treatment.  

Option Analysis

✅ Administer IV fluids:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Administer octreotide:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation is very suggestive of cirrhosis with likely variceal bleeding. Octreotide bolus followed by drip is indicated in the setting of acute variceal bleeding because it lowers portal venous pressure. This can be started after the patient has first been hemodynamically stabilized with IV fluids.  
❌ Administer a beta-blocker:
Incorrect: Beta-blockers are used after the diagnosis of esophageal varices has been confirmed to reduce the risk of rebleeding in the future. They are not appropriate at this time in this patient who is hemodynamic unstable.  
❌ Administer antibiotics:
Incorrect: Treatment with prophylactic antibiotics (e.g. ceftriaxone) is part of the management of patients with cirrhosis who present with acute variceal bleeding. However, the first priority is the hemodynamic stability of this patient.  
❌ Perform paracentesis:
Incorrect: This patient has hemodynamic instability and must be stabilized before any procedures are done. This patient’s abdominal distension and positive fluid wave indicate ascites and paracentesis should be performed after the patient is stabilized.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man is seen in the emergency department for evaluation of abdominal pain and black stool for the past six days. The patient normally drinks 11 beers per day, but his last drink was five days ago due to abdominal pain. The patient is prescribed omeprazole for peptic ulcer disease but does not take this medication. Temperature is 37.2 ºC (99.0 ºF), pulse is 90/min, blood pressure is 122/81 mmHg, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 100% on room air. On physical examination, the patient has normal mentation and no asterixis. There is mild epigastric and right upper quadrant tenderness to palpation. Digital rectal examination shows black stool in the rectal vault without hematochezia. Hemoglobin is 11.1 g/dL, AST is 175 U/L and ALT is 90 U/L. The patient’s Maddrey discriminant function is calculated as 39. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Transfer to a liver transplant center

questions.solution:
This patient with alcohol use disorder presents with right upper quadrant abdominal pain, elevated transaminases, and a severely elevated Maddrey discriminant function, indicating alcohol-induced hepatitis. This patient has known peptic ulcer disease which is likely causing a subacute or chronic upper GI bleed, complicating management of the hepatitis.

After diagnosing alcohol-induced hepatitis, the next step is to calculate the Maddrey discriminant function (DF or Maddrey score) which uses total bilirubin and prothrombin time (PT) to calculate a number. If that number is >32, it indicates advanced liver injury and inpatient treatment should be started with intravenous steroids or pentoxifylline if steroids are contraindicated. The MELD (model for end-stage liver disease) score can also be used, and it uses sodium, creatinine, total bilirubin, and INR. A MELD score >20 indicates advanced injury and the need for treatment. Patients with DF ≤32 and/or MELD ≤20 should receive supportive care without steroids or pentoxifylline.

Prednisone is converted to prednisolone in the liver, so patients with alcohol-induced hepatitis should be treated with (methyl)prednisolone rather than prednisone as this conversion may be impaired. In patients with contraindications to corticosteroids (e.g., active GI bleed, active infection), pentoxifylline should be given instead. In patients receiving treatment, the Lille score should be calculated after several days of treatment to determine response to treatment and whether or not patients should stay on the treatment. The underlying alcohol use disorder must always be addressed in patients with alcohol-induced hepatitis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Start oral pentoxifylline:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Start oral prednisolone:
Incorrect: Oral prednisolone is indicated for alcohol-induced hepatitis in patients with a Maddrey discriminant function >32. In patients, like this one, with contraindications to steroids (e.g. active GI bleed), pentoxifylline should be used instead.  
❌ Calculate MELD score:
Incorrect: This patient’s Maddrey discriminant function is >32 which indicates that treatment should be started. Calculating the MELD score is unnecessary at this point as this patient already has an indication for treatment.  
❌ Transfer to a liver transplant center:
Incorrect: This would be appropriate if this patient had acute/fulminant liver failure, however he has alcohol-induced hepatitis.  
❌ Start IV lorazepam:
Incorrect: This patient’s last drink was more than four days ago. He is outside the window for having significant withdrawal syndromes (usually 48-72 hours) and would not need benzodiazepines.

questions.text:
A 43-year-old woman comes to the clinic for a follow up. She has been experiencing occasional nausea. Past medical history is significant for ulcerative colitis for which she takes mesalamine. The last flare of ulcerative colitis was 2 years ago and was treated with a short course of intravenous steroids followed by an oral taper. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Vitals are within normal limits. BMI is 37 kg/m2. Physical examination is unremarkable and there is no organomegaly. Labs are ordered and results are shown below. Right upper quadrant ultrasound is inconclusive due to body habitus. Which of the following is the next best step in management?  

Laboratory value  
Result
Serum Chemistry

Sodium
142 mEq/L
Potassium
4.2 mEq/L
Chloride
95 mEq/L  
Creatinine
1.2 mg/dL  
Liver Function Test

Total bilirubin  
1.4 mg/dL  
Direct bilirubin  
0.8
Alkaline phosphatase  
310 U/L
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT)  
25 U/L
Aspartate aminotransferase (AST)  
21 U/L
Gamma-glutamyl transferase  
120 U/L (normal 0-30 U/L)  
Albumin
4 g/dL

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen with contrast

questions.solution:
This patient with a past medical history of ulcerative colitis, occasional nausea and a cholestatic pattern of liver disease on bloodwork most likely has primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC). Diagnosis is made with demonstration of a multifocal stricturing pattern with focal dilation (beaded appearance) of hepatic bile ducts via magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP).

PSC is a chronic, progressive inflammatory disorder of the intrahepatic and/or extrahepatic bile ducts, which causes fibrosis and stricture formation within the biliary tree, with eventual cirrhosis. Most patients are asymptomatic, with incidental finding of isolated elevation of alkaline phosphatase (ALP) or a cholestatic pattern of liver disease (i.e., elevated ALP, total bilirubin, gamma-glutamyl transferase with relatively normal AST and ALT). Patients with advanced disease can have abdominal pain, fatigue, pruritus, weight loss and mild elevation of aminotransferases (typically <300 U/L).

Ultrasound can show segmental biliary duct dilation with wall thickening of medium or large intrahepatic or extrahepatic bile ducts, but can be inconclusive in morbidly obese patients. Diagnosis is made by demonstration of a multifocal stricturing pattern with focal dilation (beaded appearance) of hepatic bile ducts via magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP). ERCP can be performed to evaluate very early disease or in patients who can not tolerate MRI (e.g. metal implants, pacemaker).
 

Option Analysis

✅ Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP)  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Liver biopsy:
Incorrect: Liver biopsy is invasive and is rarely diagnostic. The classic “onion skin” pattern of fibrous obliteration is seen only in a minority of patients. Moreover, it does not change management. It is reserved for patients where there is high clinical suspicion of autoimmune cholestatic liver disease but negative cholangiography, in order to evaluate for small duct PSC or PSC-autoimmune hepatitis overlap syndrome.  
❌ CT scan of the abdomen with contrast:
Incorrect: This patient exhibits a cholestatic pattern of liver disease. CT scans are relatively nonspecific in differentiating the cause of cholestasis. MRCP is more sensitive and specific for diagnosis of cholestatic liver disease.  
❌ Bone scan:
Incorrect: Elevated alkaline phosphatase secondary to rapid bone turnover can be seen in patients with Paget disease, osteomalacia, or bone-forming metastatic disease. Bone scan would be helpful for evaluation of bone-related elevations of alkaline phosphatase. However, high gamma glutamyltransferase levels indicate a hepatic source of elevated alkaline phosphatase in this patient.  
❌ Anti–smooth muscle antibody levels:
Incorrect: Though anti-smooth muscle antibodies can be seen in patients with primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC), their clinical significance is not well-defined. Anti-smooth muscle antibody has a higher specificity for diagnosis of autoimmune hepatitis. This test should not be used to rule out or rule in PSC.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of progressive abdominal distention and pain over the past 2 days. He has a history of alcohol-associated cirrhosis that was diagnosed 7 years ago. A recent contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) scan diagnosed hepatocellular carcinoma. Temperature is 37℃ (98.6℉), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 122/84 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Abdominal examination reveals a distended and tender abdomen without rebound or guarding. There is a positive fluid wave and spider angiomas are present. An ultrasound with Doppler of the abdomen shows impaired blood flow and a hyperechoic mass extending into the portal vein. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) presents with worsening abdominal distension, new-onset abdominal pain, and doppler ultrasound confirming acute portal vein thrombosis. For this patient with underlying HCC, the most appropriate treatment is chemotherapy.  

Patients with portal vein thrombosis (PVT) secondary to underlying hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), should be managed differently from other patients with PVT, due to the complexities introduced by the cancer itself and its associated risks. The use of anticoagulation, typically the standard of care in PVT cases, is generally avoided in HCC-related PVT due to increased bleeding risks and limited efficacy. Focus shifts toward managing the primary malignancy and alleviating symptoms with systemic chemotherapy. Sorafenib, a tyrosine kinase inhibitor, is commonly used in the treatment of advanced HCC. It has been shown to improve survival and to manage the systemic effects of HCC. The goal of treatment is to control the progression of HCC.  

Option Analysis

✅ Chemotherapy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH):
Incorrect: Anticoagulation is not indicated in acute portal vein thrombosis secondary to hepatocellular carcinoma as there is an increased risk of bleeding from the tumor and limited efficacy of anticoagulants in malignancy-related thrombotic conditions.
❌ Upper endoscopy:
Incorrect: Upper endoscopy is indicated in patients with portal vein thrombosis (PVT) presenting with variceal hemorrhage, or for screening in patients with cirrhosis and PVT who are being started on LMWH.
❌ Surgical thrombectomy:
Incorrect: Surgical thrombectomy is reserved for patients who are undergoing surgery for intestinal infarction and portal vein thrombosis (PVT), where thrombectomy can be performed during the laparotomy. 
❌ Thrombolytic therapy:
Incorrect: Systemic thrombolytic therapy is not an appropriate management option for acute portal vein thrombus.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents to his primary care physician because he has been having intermittent vomiting and abdominal pain. This has occurred occasionally over the past three years but has been occurring more frequently for the past few months. Abdominal pain occurs after eating and is located in the upper abdomen with radiation to the back. The patient’s stools seem to be “greasy” and are difficult to flush. He has no melena or hematochezia. He drinks three glasses of whiskey every evening and six beers per day. He smokes one pack of cigarettes per day. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and blood pressure is 142/92 mmHg. On physical examination, there is mild epigastric tenderness to palpation. Laboratory studies show serum C-reactive protein of 0.2 mg/dL, serum lipase of 138 U/L, and fecal elastase of 152 µg/g (normal = >200 µg/g). Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Computed tomography of the abdomen with pancreatic protocol

questions.solution:
This patient’s recurrent episodes of vomiting and radiating abdominal pain, associated with steatorrhea and low fecal elastase, are suggestive of chronic pancreatitis.

Computed tomography of the abdomen with pancreatic protocol or magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography should be performed to evaluate for chronic pancreatitis. Excessive alcohol use and smoking are both risk factors for this condition.

When formulating a differential diagnosis for patients with chronic vomiting, it is helpful to determine if the cause is abdominal or non-abdominal.  In patients with a likely abdominal cause, the location and nature of abdominal pain, description of bowel movements, timing of symptoms concerning meals, physical examination findings, and risk factors can all help further narrow the differential. Laboratory studies such as complete blood count, inflammatory markers, pancreatic enzymes, and stool studies can be performed. Cross-sectional imaging or direct endoscopic visualization may be required depending on the most likely etiology. 

Chronic pancreatitis typically causes long-standing episodic or persistent epigastric abdominal pain, often with radiation to the back. Steatorrhea and epigastric tenderness are common. Risk factors include excessive alcohol consumption, smoking, hypertriglyceridemia, autoimmune conditions, genetic conditions, and direct insult to the pancreas either through injury or infection. Amylase and lipase may be elevated early in the course of the disease but may be normal or low later. Fecal elastase less than or equal to 200 µg/g is suggestive of chronic pancreatitis and should prompt further investigation with CT or MRI.    

Option Analysis

✅ Computed tomography of the abdomen with pancreatic protocol:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) :
Incorrect: An EGD helps evaluate conditions such as gastroesophageal reflux disease, peptic ulcer disease, gastroparesis, and other disorders of the esophagus and stomach lining.  This patient’s symptoms and laboratory findings are suggestive of chronic pancreatitis for which CT is indicated.  
❌ Colonoscopy:
Incorrect: A colonoscopy helps evaluate conditions such as inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Patients with IBD may also have low fecal elastase, however, typically inflammatory markers will be elevated. This patient’s history and findings are more consistent with chronic pancreatitis.  
❌ Endoscopic ultrasound:
Incorrect: Endoscopic ultrasound is a useful test for evaluating the pancreas and can be utilized in patients with suspected chronic pancreatitis with equivocal CT or MRI imaging. This patient has not yet had initial imaging with CT of the abdomen.  
❌ Gastric emptying study:
Incorrect: A gastric emptying study is useful in cases of suspected gastroparesis. This patient’s clinical symptoms of radiating epigastric pain and steatorrhea along with his physical exam and low fecal elastase are suggestive of chronic pancreatitis.

questions.text: A 38-year-old G3P2 woman at 31 weeks gestation presents to her obstetrician for evaluation of intense pruritus. The patient reports itching primarily over her palms and soles and states that symptoms worsen at night. She has no abdominal pain, nausea, or vomiting. The patient has a history of idiopathic pancreatitis but does not take any daily medication. She has not been drinking alcohol since becoming pregnant and has no history of recreational drug use. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 112/60 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates a gravid abdomen consistent with gestational age, without tenderness to palpation. There are excoriations over the palms and soles. Which of the following laboratory findings would be most indicative of the likely underlying condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with pruritus of the palms and soles in the third trimester of pregnancy, which is concerning for intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy (ICP). A defining characteristic of this condition in laboratory analysis is an elevation in total bile acid levels > 10 µmol/L. An elevated total bile acid concentration is seen in over 90% of patients with ICP.  

ICP is a rare pregnancy-specific liver disease characterized by pruritus and elevated serum bile acid levels. Genetic susceptibility and changes in hormone levels (namely estrogen) in pregnancy disrupt the expression of receptors and transport proteins necessary for maintaining normal bile acid homeostasis, resulting in elevated bile acid concentrations. ICP typically presents in the third trimester with itching on the palms of the hands and soles of the feet, without a rash. However, intense pruritus can lead to excoriations due to scratching.  

When suspected, diagnosis can be confirmed via detection of an elevation in total bile acid levels > 10 µmol/L. Supporting findings may include mild elevations in transaminases, bilirubin, and alkaline phosphatase. Other causes of pruritus and transaminitis, if present, should be ruled out. Ideally, total bile acids should be checked in a fasting state, due to small discrepancy in levels between fasting and random blood work. When elevated, patients should have labs repeated, as rising levels of total bile acid are associated with poorer fetal outcomes, which may change management. 

Option Analysis

✅ Total bile acids > 10 µmol/L:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ 2:1 AST/ALT ratio:
Incorrect: A 2:1 AST/ALT ratio is seen in alcohol misuse. This patient's presentation is consistent with ICP and while mild transaminitis can occur in patients with ICP, a 2:1 ratio would not be expected. An elevated total bile acid concentration is seen in most patients with ICP.
❌ Positive antimitochondrial antibodies :
Incorrect: Positive antimitochondrial antibodies are present in patients with primary biliary cholangitis, which is an autoimmune disorder that affects the small and medium intrahepatic bile ducts leading to cholestasis. This patient's clinical presentation is more consistent with intrahepatic cholestasis in pregnancy, where mild transaminitis and elevated total bile acids are typically seen. 
❌ Thrombocytopenia:
Incorrect: Thrombocytopenia and significant transaminitis are seen in patients with HELLP syndrome. Patients with this condition typically have malaise hypertension and abdominal pain, they do not typically have intense pruritus of the palms and soles which is associated with ICP and elevated bile acids.
❌ Elevated alkaline phosphatase:
Incorrect: An elevated alkaline phosphatase level can be seen in patients with ICP; however, it is not specific given the presence of placental alkaline phosphatase. Elevated bile acid concentrations are seen in most patients with ICP.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old G4P3 woman at 30 weeks gestation presents to her obstetrician for routine evaluation. The patient states that she has been experiencing difficulty sleeping at night due to constant itching. She has no other symptoms that are bothering her at this time. She has a history of asthma that is well-controlled with an as-needed albuterol inhaler. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 102/60 mmHg, pulse is 105/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates a gravid abdomen consistent with 30 weeks gestation, without tenderness to palpation. Cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits. Laboratory results are detailed below. Which of the following findings is most likely to be seen on physical exam given the likely underlying diagnosis?

 Laboratory value  Result 
 Complete Blood Count 
 Hemoglobin  13.5 g/dL 
 Leukocyte count  5500/mm3 
 Platelet Count  300,000/mm3 
 Serum Chemistry 
 Sodium   142 mEq/L 
 Potassium   4.2 mEq/L 
 Chloride  95 mEq/L 
 Creatinine   0.8 mg/dL 
 Alanine aminotransferase  75 U/L 
 Aspartate aminotransferase  68 U/L 
 Serum albumin  4 g/dL 
 Serum total bilirubin  2.2 mg/dL 
 Alkaline phosphatase level   220 U/L 
 Total bile acids   14 µmol/L

choices.text: Excoriations on the palms and soles
Vesicular lesions in a dermatomal distribution

questions.solution:
This patient presents with pruritis in the third trimester of pregnancy, and laboratory studies show elevated total bile acid levels and mild transaminitis. These findings are consistent with intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy (ICP) which is associated with pruritus of the palms and soles. Patients often present with excoriations on the palms and soles.    

ICP is a rare pregnancy-specific liver disease characterized by pruritus and elevated serum bile acid levels. Patients typically present in the third trimester with itching on the palms of the hands and soles of the feet, without a rash. Jaundice can occur occasionally, but it is typically mild. ICP is associated with poor fetal outcomes, including preterm delivery, meconium-stained amniotic fluid, and stillbirth. These are attributed to the accumulation of bile acids in the fetus and amniotic fluid.  

Risk factors for ICP include a personal or family history of ICP, preexisting hepatitis C, non-alcoholic cirrhosis, non-alcoholic pancreatitis, and history of gallstones and cholecystitis. ICP is also associated with advanced maternal age, multiple gestations, and in vitro fertilization. On physical examination, patients will often have excoriations due to scratching; however, no rash is associated with the disease. This differentiates ICP from other pregnancy-specific pruritic dermatoses and skin conditions that are unrelated to pregnancy.

Option Analysis

✅ Excoriations on the palms and soles:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Jaundice:
Incorrect: Jaundice is less commonly associated with cholestasis in pregnancy. It occurs in approximately 14-25% of patients with this condition. Excoriations on the palms and soles are more likely.
❌ Erythematous urticarial plaques and papules:
Incorrect: Pemphigoid gestationis is a rare dermatosis of pregnancy and is similar to bullous pemphigoid. Skin findings include erythematous urticarial plaques and papules. This patient's clinical picture is consistent with ICP. Patients often present with excoriations of the palms and soles.
❌ Eczematous lesions in skin folds:
Incorrect: Patients with atopic eruption of pregnancy present with eczematous lesions over flexural surfaces. Cholestasis of pregnancy is not associated with a rash, but excoriations on the palms and soles if often seen. 
❌ Vesicular lesions in a dermatomal distribution:
Incorrect: Vesicular lesions in a dermatomal distribution are suggestive of herpes zoster, or shingles. This patient's presentation is more consistent with ICP.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old G5P4 woman at 33 weeks gestation presents to her obstetrician for evaluation of intense pruritus at night primarily over her palms and soles. The patient's early pregnancy was complicated by hyperemesis gravidarum; however, the patient has not had any recent nausea or vomiting. The patient has a history of seasonal allergies but does not take any medication daily. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 121/67 mmHg, pulse is 85/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates a gravid abdomen without tenderness to palpation. There are excoriations over the patient’s palms and soles. Laboratory results are detailed below. Which of the following is the best next step in treatment?

 Laboratory value  Result 
 Complete Blood Count 
 Hemoglobin  13.2 g/dL 
 Leukocyte count  6500/mm3 
 Platelet Count  312,000/mm3 
 Serum Chemistry 
 Sodium   141 mEq/L 
 Potassium   4.3 mEq/L 
 Chloride  97 mEq/L 
 Creatinine   0.8 mg/dL 
 Alanine aminotransferase  88 U/L 
 Aspartate aminotransferase  69 U/L 
 Serum albumin  4.1 g/dL 
 Serum total bilirubin  1.7 mg/dL 
 Alkaline phosphatase level   225 U/L 
 Total bile acids   22 µmol/L
questions.solution:
This patient presents with pruritus of the palms and soles in the third trimester of pregnancy and an elevated bile acid concentration consistent with intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy (ICP). Preferred treatment for pruritus from ICP is ursodeoxycholic acid. Patients like this one with bile acid levels between 10 and 99 µmol/L should have delivery planned for anytime between 36 weeks and 0 days to 39 weeks and 0 days.    

ICP is a rare pregnancy-specific liver disease characterized by pruritus and elevated serum bile acid levels. ICP is associated with poor fetal outcomes, including preterm delivery, meconium-stained amniotic fluid, and stillbirth. These outcomes are felt to be due to accumulation of bile acids in the fetus and amniotic fluid.    

The preferred treatment for pruritus from ICP is ursodeoxycholic acid, which can be titrated to reduce pruritus. The antihistamine (e.g. diphenhydramine) can be used in patients who cannot take ursodeoxycholic acid. Importantly, ursodeoxycholic acid does not change fetal outcomes.   

When ICP is diagnosed, antenatal fetal surveillance with non-stress tests and assessment of amniotic fluid volume should be performed weekly and delivery should be planned based on the level of total serum bile acids, in order to improve fetal outcomes. Patients with serum bile acid levels of 10-99 µmol/L should deliver between 36 0/7 weeks - 39 0/7 weeks, and patients with total bile acid concentration ≥ 100 µmol/L should deliver early at 36 0/7 weeks to improve fetal outcomes. 

Option Analysis

✅ Ursodeoxycholic acid:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hydroxyzine:
Incorrect: While the antihistamine hydroxyzine can be used to treat intense pruritus, it should not be prescribed during pregnancy. Diphenhydramine could be used in patients who cannot take ursodeoxycholic acid.
❌ Immediate fetal induction and delivery:
Incorrect: Immediate delivery is not indicated in this patient given that the bile acid level is between 10 and 99 µmol/L. Symptomatic treatment with ursodeoxycholic acid and delivery at anywhere from 36 weeks and 0 days to 39 weeks and 0 days is the most appropriate management for this patient. 
❌ Thiamine:
Incorrect: Thiamine should be considered as an adjunctive treatment for patients with hyperemesis gravidarum. It is not indicated in the treatment of ICP. 
❌ Observation and delivery at 36 weeks :
Incorrect: Given this patient's bile acid concentration, delivery is recommended between 36 weeks and 0 days to 39 weeks and 0 days. Treatment with ursodeoxycholic acid should be implemented in the meantime to manage the patient’s symptoms.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parent for evaluation of intractable vomiting and lethargy. The patient’s parent reports that the family was on vacation for the past six days. Three days ago, the patient developed a headache, cough, coryza, sore throat and a temperature of 39.2°C (102.6°F).
